addressleaf.section:
2 N
o
1592
M
r
Bodeleie to
e LL
S
r
Nicholas Parkers
Horseband
.

To the right honorable my very singular good Lordes the Lordes and others of her Hig
es
privie Councel.

page.lettertext:
fol.331r
May it please yo
r
good LL. for that Whiche is
required by yo
r
LL. letter of the 17 of October,
enjoining
e dispatche of S
r
Nicholas Parkers horsband,
I have advertised at large what impediments I found,
w
ch
I hope are already imparted to yo
r
LL. if my
letter therupon, which I addressed of late unto my
L. Treasurer
be safely delivered. S
r
Nicholas Parker
hath bin ready, as muche as lay in him, sins
e time
that
e armie of
e states was dissolved. But by
reason I had no order, for
e place of his Rendevous,
I was forced to forbeare, from urging his departure.
For to embarke all his horses, and to attend a winds
in
Zeland
, w
t
e compa nies of foote, considering
e
uncertaintie of getting shipping for [
Jeresey
], it was
thought it would prove
e overthrowe of
e troupe.
Moreover though
e states have bin solicited,
to graunt him a pasport, to remove from
Duisbourgh
to
Berghen
, Where
S
r
John Poley
is in garrison, to
have
e better commoditie for supplie of his companie,
they doe not onely refuse to admitte him into Berghen,
but they will give him no pasport for any other
place. Whether they thinke by
at meanes, to stay
him heere for all together, or to lette him from di-
minishing S
r
John Poleis Cornet, I can not certifie
yo
r
LL. but assoone as I have notice of
e place
of
e Rendevous, I will take as good a course as
is possible for me, to procure him a passage: and
w
t
all I will use w
at
meanes I am able, to helpe S
r
John Poley, to convey his horses to him. I knowe it
fol.331v
will prove a troublesome attempt, if
e states be
unwilling: but except they doe resist in violent
sort, w
ch
I thinke they will not doe, I hope I shall
effect it. S
r
Nicholas Parker himself I have
founde very forward to doe any thing required:
and though it be apparant,
at by this last sommer
service many of his souldiers are unmounted and
also divers of his horses
dead and
very greatly
decaied, whereby
his numbers are abated, yet I take his band, as
it is, to be
e best in order, and most sufficient in
this contrey. He maketh no doubt of per-
suading divers of his souldiers, w
ch
are of this contrey
and men of good worth, to folowe him in this voiage,
and suche as shall refuse, for
at they are maried,
or for other respectes, he will passe them in exchange
w
t
S
r
John Poley and other Captaines: so as alwaies
her Ma
tie
shall be served of his troupe in very
good strength.
herein my best endevo
r
shall ap-
peare unto yo
r
LL.
And so I take my humble
leave. From
e Hage. N
o
2 1592
Yo
r
LL. most humble
at commaundement Tho. Bodley
